attributes.label: Request materials from SCRC
attributes.title: Request materials from SCRC
attributes.description:
You are welcome to request SCRC materials for use in our Reading Room. To do so, you will need to create an SCRC Researcher Account and complete an online request form. Please also see “Registration and Security” for assistance with this process.

Our online tools include Library Search and our Finding Aids. We also have a large news clippings and photograph collection from the Philadelphia Evening Bulletin and Philadelphia Inquirer that you can request online for in-house use.

Please keep in mind that some of our materials are housed off-site and require at least 2 days advance notice for us to retrieve boxes for use in our reading room. Our staff will contact you if materials will not be ready by your preferred visit date.

Finally, while we are constantly striving to increase the discoverability of our materials, our website only covers a small portion of our actual collections and holdings—which is over 90,000 linear feet, many terabytes, and growing. If you don't find what you are looking for on our website, we encourage you to visit, call, or email us.

How to request materials in Library Search

  1. Identify and navigate to the Library Search record for an item you’re interested in using.
  2. Click on the “Request from Special Collections” link (under the “Request” column).
  3. Log in to your SCRC Researcher Account and complete the reading room request form.
  4. Enter the date of your visit by clicking on the small calendar icon next to the date field, or manually enter the dates. You may also select “Keep For My Review” if you wish to submit the request at a later time.
  5. Click the “Submit Request” button.

How to request materials listed in our online finding aids

  1. To locate finding aids, use Library Search at the top right corner of any website page.
  2. Enter your search terms and select the link from the search results, or click “Browse All Finding Aids.”
  3. Once in the Finding Aid, click the link in the upper right hand corner of the page that says “Request materials from Special Collections Research Center.” You will be prompted to log into your SCRC Researcher Account.
  4. Complete the archival reading room request form. Be sure to include the collection id in the Call Number field and the box number.
  5. Please submit a new request for each box you would like to see.
  6. Enter the date of your visit by clicking on the small calendar icon next to the date field, or manually enter the dates. You may also select “Keep For My Review” if you wish to submit the request at a later time
  7. Click the “Submit Request” button.

How to request newspaper clippings and photographs

  1. Navigate to the finding aid of Philadelphia Evening Bulletin Philadelphia Evening Bulletin News Clipping (SCRC 169) or Photograph Collection (SCRC 170); or the Philadelphia Inquirer News Clippings (SCRC 171) or Photograph Collection (SCRC 172).
  2. Once in the finding aid, click the link in the upper right hand corner of the page that says “Request materials from Special Collections Research Center.” You will be prompted to log into your SCRC Researcher Account.
  3. Complete the archival reading room request form. Enter the subject or name of the clippings you would like to see.
  4. For faster request processing, you must submit a new request for each subject or name.
  5. Enter the date of your visit by clicking on the small calendar icon next to the date field, or manually enter the dates. You may also select “Keep For My Review” if you wish to submit the request at a later time.
  6. Click the “Submit Request” button.

After submitting a request

Staff will pull the envelopes and/or photographs and place them on hold for you in the SCRC Reading Room.
attributes.access_description: Please email the Special Collections Research Center at scrc@temple.edu.

attributes.label: Request copies of SCRC materials
attributes.title: Request copies of SCRC materials
attributes.description:
Due to the fragile and rare nature of our materials, all duplication is performed by staff members.

While we make every attempt to accommodate duplication requests, making copies is inherently stressful to the originals. For this reason we’ve established limits to balance researchers’ needs with our obligation to preserve these resources. Depending on the condition, size, and quantity of materials requested, the SCRC reserves the right to refuse a copying order if, in its judgment,

  • fulfillment of the order would damage the item,
  • involve violation of U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U. S. Code), more information about copyright issues,
  • require reproduction of a major part of a book or archives collection (we will not reproduce more than 20 percent of any book, manuscript, or collection),
  • or entail the use of excessive staff time and resources.

Cameras use is allowed in the reading room. Please see this link for our cameras use policy.

For some collections, we require use of microfilm or digital copies in place of originals when film or digital copies are available and the originals are at risk.
attributes.access_description: Please email the Special Collections Research Center at scrc@temple.edu.
attributes.service_policies:
Duplication fees and payment

  • All requests must be accompanied by a signed Reproduction Request Form.
  • All orders must be paid in advance.  We accept payment by cash, check, or credit card.
  • Please make checks payable to "Temple University" and write SCRC in the memo line.  
  • International postage will be added at time of request.
  • If you wish to pay by credit card, there is a $15 minimum charge. We accept Visa, MasterCard, American Express, Discover, Diners Club, or JCB. To complete a credit card transaction, please call us at 215-204-8257, during business hours, Monday through Friday, from 8:30 am to 5:30 pm. Please do not leave credit card information on a voicemail or in an email.

Photocopy rates

  • $.25/page, selected by patron
  • $.35/page, mail order/selected by staff, up to 100 copies
  • $.40/page, mail order/selected by staff, up to 200 copies

Postage

  • up to 15 pages - $1.50
  • up to 25 pages - $1.75
  • up to 50 pages - $2.50
  • up to 100 pages - USPS rate

Rush fee (optional)

 

Rush turnaround for photographic, cassette, or video duplication may be available for a 50% additional charge with advance payment. Please contact SCRC staff for terms and costs.

 

Digital Scans

  • Scan per image: $5.00
  • STUDENT RATES (elementary school through graduate school): First 10 image prints or scans free—per project

For pricing on oversized or other unusual sized materials please contact a staff member.

 

Image format and delivery

 

Images will be scanned at 600 dpi or less and at the original size. TIFF and JPEG formats are available. JPEG files may be transmitted by email. TIFF images will be delivered via Temple University’s digital dropbox service, TUsafesend, or on a CD ROM, for a fee of $5.

 

Audio Duplication

 

Contact a staff member to ask about fees for cassette to digital (in-house) and reel-to-reel to digital (external vendor) audio duplication. 

 

Film/Video Duplication

 

The SCRC provides access to AV materials for in-house use and duplication to students, faculty, and guests for educational and research purposes. Fees and policies vary according to use.

 

For information about reproduction and licensing of some collections for publication or commercial use, please contact a staff member.  

 

The SCRC will provide user copies of footage that has been transferred to a duplicating master. If the footage has not been transferred to a duplicating master, the user will be required to bear the costs of reformatting prior to viewing. There are some formats that cannot be transferred in-house and must be sent to a vendor.

 

Preservation and access fees

  • Copying (in-house)/In-house use: $15/reel or tape; first 3 free
  • Additional screener DVDs: $25.00 per reel/tape
  • Copying by outside vendor: $400.00/30 min, $435.00/60 min
  • Copying pre-existing digital copy: $50/hour of product

Image Publication and Fees

 

Please use the Permission to Publish contract to request permission to publish images from our holdings.  A fee, in addition to reproduction costs, may be charged on published reproductions from our holdings. Publication includes film, video, videodisc, CD-ROM, web, and exhibit. The fee must be accompanied by a completed Permission to Publish contract for each use.

  • Temple Community: Fee waived
  • Non-Profit (with IRS tax-exempt number) $25.00; $10.00 for each additional
  • For-Profit $75.00; $50 for each additional

attributes.label: Research impact & scholarly credentials
attributes.title: Research impact & scholarly credentials
attributes.description:
We assist researchers to document the significance of their impact on research using tools that measure this impact. We can also help faculty better understand the tools that measure, or claim to measure, impact and their limitations.

Research impact is an important factor as researchers work to:

  • support applications for tenure or promotion
  • justify requests for grants and other funding
  • determine how their research is being used
  • identify who is using their work
  • identify other researchers, and potential collaborators, in their field

In addition, the Research Impact and Scholarly Credentials Reference Guide includes information, tools, and suggestions for documenting the significance of scholarly credentials and accomplishments.
attributes.access_description: Contact a subject librarian to show you how to track citations to your work and how to measure your research impact.

attributes.label: Schedule a library instruction session
attributes.title: Schedule a library instruction session
attributes.description:
Faculty can request library instruction sessions for their courses. Most classes are held in the library, but presentations can be done in almost any location. Instructors must plan to attend the session with their students.

We also offer class instruction sessions in the Specials Collections Research Center (SCRC) in order to introduce students to rare books, archives, manuscripts, and other media — such as photographs, film and digital media — that include content related to their coursework and research projects. Information about our collections, and possibilities for session or assignment topics, can be found by reading more about our collecting areas.

Schedule instruction at Charles Library, Ambler Campus Library, or the Health Sciences Libraries

  1. Submit an online request or contact the library's subject librarian for your department directly. Library instruction sessions should be scheduled at least a full week in advance.  
  2. Contact the library's subject librarian for your department to discuss what will be covered in the session. Sessions can be tailored to address specific assignments or concerns for your class.    

Schedule instruction in the Special Collections Research Center

  1. Fill out the Instruction Session/Visit Request Form, ideally at least two weeks in advance of your planned visit.  
  2. We’ll work with you to tailor the instruction session to your course's subject matter and learning objectives. 

SCRC staff offer a variety of instruction formats, basic research orientations, and specialized sessions that incorporate course- or assignment-based resources and activities. These sessions are geared toward teaching students how to conduct research using primary sources (primary source literacy), and enhancing their research, critical thinking, and writing skills.

Guides to selected topics and subjects available for research in the Special Collections Research Center can be found on the SCRC Research Guides page. More will be added soon.

In addition to working with students in class sessions, we can place materials on hold in our reading room for student use in course assignments.

Additional questions?

Please direct any questions regarding class visits to Josué Hurtado, Coordinator of Public Services & Outreach, or to scrc@temple.edu.

attributes.label: Cultural Analytics Certificate Program
attributes.title: Cultural Analytics Certificate Program
attributes.description:
What is Cultural Analytics?

“Cultural Analytics” refers to the analysis of cultural objects assisted by computers.

Much of modern culture exists in digital form. Digital versions of traditional humanistic materials—books, films, paintings, sculptures, and artifacts―are readily available for study. Graduate students who work with digital materials benefit from specialized training in managing and manipulating their materials, so that they can take full advantage of its digital form.

What is the Cultural Analytics program?

Open to all students, the program is an interdisciplinary effort by the College of Liberal Arts, Klein College of Media and Communication, Tyler School of Art, the School of Education, the Center for the Performing and Cinematic Arts, the College of Science and Technology, and Temple University Libraries. We work together to train graduate students how to use computational methods to study images, books, objects, and other cultural products.

The certificate program prepares students for advanced research in their discipline by allowing them to specialize in the specific skills that are most relevant to their research. It encourages participants to work within one of the following focal areas:

  • data visualization

  • mapping and geographic information systems

  • basic programming

  • research design and analysis

  • statistics

  • social media research

  • text encoding and analysis

  • virtual environments

Because of the intersecting needs for training in these methods, we recognize that we can offer a stronger certificate program by joining forces than by creating overlapping programs on our own. The course of study supplements instruction offered by each student's degree program by enabling students to learn the techniques they need to use cultural analytics professionally in the dissertation, thesis, or culminating event.

As such, it strengthens their degree-related research and leads to more innovative projects and grant-funding possibilities than would otherwise be possible. Students are expected to work closely with their academic adviser throughout their certificate progress.

What are the program requirements?

Students must take 9 credits of coursework and a variable credit (0-1) practicum to complete the Certificate.

The curriculum begins with an introductory course that surveys the full range of current research methods in the field, so that students are aware of the different techniques they can apply to their own research questions. This survey is followed by two electives selected from a list of courses that represent the distinct methodological emphases in the field, giving students a chance to gain a solid understanding of the conceptual and technical material they need to master.

The concluding experience is a workshop in which students complete a research project for the dissertation, thesis, or culminating event. The workshop is overseen by staff from the Scholars Studio of Temple Libraries. This facility has both the equipment and the technical expertise to guide students in the process of completing their projects, and the workshop format gives all participating students a community to work with during the process.

Because this final project is intended as part of their graduate program, students are required to work closely with their academic adviser. Both the workshop director and academic adviser must assign a passing grade to the final project for successful completion of the certificate program.

Why should I apply?

The certificate will be a valuable asset for students seeking academic careers. While the overall number of tenure track jobs has declined in recent years, the prevalence of listings requiring skills in digital research or analytics has increased.

The certificate also opens up new career paths for students interested in using their M.A., M.S, M.F.A., or Ph.D. outside the academy. These skills enhance their chances for finding positions in a range of careers, from private businesses to museums and archives.

How do I apply?

Fall and Spring: Admission is on a rolling basis. Students currently enrolled in a graduate degree program at Temple University must submit a personal statement of no more than 250 words and complete the Internal Application Form.

Applicants not currently enrolled at Temple are welcome. Please submit a personal statement of no more than 250 words and complete the External Application Form. External applicants must also submit official transcripts for all coursework taken since high school, whether or not a degree was earned from the institution(s). Evidence of the award of a baccalaureate degree from an accredited university must be shown.

Bachelor's Degree in Discipline/Related Discipline: Applicants already admitted to a graduate degree program at Temple University have demonstrated that they possess the required bachelor's degree. Applicants not currently enrolled in a Temple University graduate degree program and applicants enrolled in a graduate degree program at another university must submit official transcripts for all coursework taken since high school, whether or not a degree was earned from the institution(s). Evidence of the award of a baccalaureate degree from an accredited university with an undergraduate GPA of at least 3.0 on a 4.0 scale must be shown.

Additional Requirements for Students Not Currently Enrolled in a Graduate Degree Program at Temple University:

  • Two letters of recommendation from persons in a position to evaluate the applicant’s academic ability and accomplishments.

  • A personal statement of no more than 250 words indicating interests, plans, and objectives within the field of Cultural Analytics.

About the Certificate

This graduate certificate in Cultural Analytics trains students in humanistic and non-scientific fields how to use computational methods to analyze cultural objects. Much of modern culture originates in digital form. Digital versions of traditional humanistic materials -- books, films, paintings, sculptures, and artifacts -- are readily available for study. Graduate students who work with digital materials benefit from specialized training in managing and manipulating their materials, so that they can take full advantage of its digital form. The certificate program prepares students for advanced research in their discipline by allowing them to specialize in the specific skills that are most relevant to their research. It encourages participants to work within one of the following focal areas:

  • data visualization

  • mapping and geographic information systems

  • basic programming

  • research design and analysis

  • statistics

  • social media research

  • text encoding and analysis

  • virtual environments

This Certificate facilitates work on a dissertation, thesis, or culminating event by offering training in these technical skills along with the conceptual background needed to understand the opportunities and obstacles each method brings with it. Students must take 9 credits of course work and a variable credit (0-1) practicum to complete the Certificate. The introductory course surveys the range of methods. Students then select two electives in the focal area needed for their own research interests. Finally, students complete a project of their own design in the Practicum, a semester-long workshop offered by the Digital Scholarship Center/Scholars Studio of Temple University Libraries. For students currently enrolled in a graduate degree program, the final project will be part of the dissertation or thesis and will be overseen by their academic adviser. Non-matriculated students will sign up for a one-credit independent study with a faculty member who can serve as an academic adviser on their project.

Campus Location

Main

Time Limit for Certificate Completion

3 years

Full-Time/Part-Time Status

The graduate certificate can be completed on a part-time basis.

Non-Matriculated Student Policy

Non-matriculated students may take up to 9 credits of coursework before applying to the graduate certificate program. When they complete 9 credits, they must declare their intention to complete the graduate certificate in Cultural Analytics by completing and submitting the "Non-Degree Seeking Student Request to Exceed 9 Credits of Graduate Coursework for Certificate Program," found in TUportal under the Tools tab within "University Forms".

Admission Requirements and Deadlines

Bachelor's Degree in Discipline/Related Discipline

All applicants must present credentials that are the equivalent of the appropriate baccalaureate degree at Temple University. A minimum GPA of 3.0 is expected. Current enrollment in a graduate program at Temple University will be considered sufficient evidence of a baccalaureate degree.

Non-enrolled applicants must submit the External Application Form to register for courses in the Certificate program. They must also arrange for official transcripts for all coursework since high school to be sent to the CAC program administrator: Marianne Moll at marianne.moll@temple.edu.

Certificate Requirements

Number of Didactic Credits Required to Complete the Certificate: Matriculated students: 9; Non- matriculated students: 10.

Electives are grouped by focal area. Some courses satisfy multiple focal areas and these are indicated with footnotes.

Required Courses

Core Courses

  • CLA 5019 -- Introduction to Cultural Analytics

  • or History 51521 -- Digital History

  • MMC 9087 -- Cultural Analytics Practicum

Electives

Select two of the following

Data Visualization

  • GUS 50733 -- Geovisualization

  • GAD 5078 -- The Art of Infographics

Mapping

  • GUS 5062 -- Fundamentals of GIS

  • GUS 8065 -- Cartographic Design

attributes.label: Innovative Teaching with Makerspace Technology Grant
attributes.title: Innovative Teaching with Makerspace Technology Grant
attributes.description:
The application deadline for 2019-2020 closes May 6th.

Sponsored by the Center for the Advancement of Teaching (CAT) and the Digital Scholarship Center/Innovation Space, University Libraries

Makerspace technologies can help faculty to build a richer and more engaging learning experience for students. The Makerspace in Charles Library and the Innovation Space provides a hands-on environment in which students can work with a variety of digital fabrication tools, virtual reality, and electronics in order to explore and develop new ideas. These tools can be embedded in assignments and projects in order to help students learn and receive hands-on experience with the kinds of technologies they may use in the future. Some of these are free for students and faculty to use, but others involve costs associated with the materials needed to use the tools. This grant allows faculty interested in exploring ways to use Makerspace technologies in the classroom the possibility to try them in fall 2019 or spring 2020 without passing the cost on to the students. A more thorough overview of the technologies offered within the Makerspace can be found here.

Faculty committed to:

  • Receiving any necessary pedagogical or technological training on using the tools from the Center for the Advancement of Teaching or the Charles Library Makerspace/Innovation Space before the semester in which the tool is implemented. Support may include meeting with a consultant to plan effective use of the tool.
  • Testing the use of the tool before implementing it in the classroom.
  • Submitting a syllabus plan for implementation by May 30th, 2019 for the fall 2019 semester or December 1, 2019 for the spring 2020 semester.
  • Piloting the chosen tool in a class in fall 2019 or spring 2020.
  • Submitting a one-page project completion report within a month of end of the semester.

Benefits:

  • Group and individual support and training in how to effectively use Makerspace technologies to engage students and help them to learn.
  • Up to $3,000 to cover the cost of materials needed to implement these technological projects in the pilot semester. Amount depends on number of students and type of technology chosen.
  • Possibility to present on your experiences with the technologies at a CAT event.

To Apply for the Innovative Teaching with Makerspace Technology Grant:

Please respond to each of the following questions in fewer than 250 words.

Note​: ​A consultation may be helpful to help you consider these questions. Please contact David Rossat Davidross@temple.edu to set up a consultation.

  1. Which Makerspace tool would you like to use in your classroom? In which class will you be using it? How do you envision using it?
  2. Explain how the use of this Makerspace tool will improve engagement and/or learning for your students. How might it be an improvement over your current practice?
  3. How will you help your students develop the skills needed to use the tool effectively?
  4. Describe your experience with the use of technology for teaching.
  5. What is the timeline for implementation of the tool.
  6. Provide an estimated cost for the project. A Digital Scholarship or Innovation Center consultant can help you with this task. Remember to think about the number of students who will need to use the tools and whether they will be individual or group projects.

Once you have completed this section of the application, please submit your document as a Word Document or PDF. Applications are to be submitted online at https://app.smartsheet.com/b/form/d2139998498849b5ab7a3564826fef00by by the due date of May 6th.

attributes.label: Assignment design support
attributes.title: Assignment design support
attributes.description:
Designing a research assignment for 21st-century learners can present unique challenges for faculty and instructors. Your liaison librarian can work with you to create assignments and in-class activities to help your students enhance their information literacy and research skills. We can also support your teaching in programs with information literacy requirements, such as GenEd and Writing Intensive Courses.
Engaging assignments might take the form of traditional research papers, but can also include writing and research utilizing digital and media literacies. Some examples of previous instructor/librarian collaborations include:
  • A faculty member whose assignment requested students to cite 5 scholarly papers was advised to add the names of specific, relevant databases, add the name of the librarian specialist for that topic with a link to making a research appointment, along with a link to a short video on how to tell the difference between a scholarly article and other types of content.
  • Two librarians and a faculty member designed a semester-long project teaching students to write original content for Wikipedia entries.
  • An Information Literacy Cross Team created an assignment that challenged students in a GenEd class to select course readings for students in subsequent semesters of the course.

attributes.label: About
attributes.title: About
attributes.description:
Research data services is a network of services throughout the Libraries to assist you during all phases of the research process. We offer tools, resources and training to help you with data management, organization, discovery, sharing, preservation and access.

Data management planning

Understand, develop and apply strategies for organizing and managing data. Learn how to craft a data management plan (DMP) for a grant application.

Finding & citing data

Search and discover existing data sources. Apply for funding to purchase or license datasets for academic research or teaching via the Library data grant program.

Library data grants program

Apply for funding to purchase or license datasets for academic research or teaching.

Data sharing & publication

Learn about best practices for sharing, publishing and citing your data. Get help to preserve your data for the future and ensure continued access.

Workshops & events

Learn about data wrangling and cleaning, analysis and visualization, text-mining, reproducibility, open science and more.

attributes.label: Finding data
attributes.title: Finding data
attributes.description:
You can use these resources to search for and discover existing data. Contact your subject librarian or email the research data services team at tul-rds@temple.edu for help finding data.

Databases

Many Library databases include datasets. From the Library homepage, select All Databases A-Z and filter results by the database type: datasets.

Selected Library databases with datasets

ICPSR is a repository of social science and interdisciplinary data for secondary data analysis and teaching.

Data-Planet Statistical DataSets provides access to statistical data produced by US federal agencies, states, private organizations, and intergovernmental organizations. Contains charts, maps, views, rankings, time series and tables.

Data Citation Index provides access to research data from repositories across disciplines and around the world. Through linked content and summary information, this data is displayed within the context of the scholarly research.

Data Discovery at the National Library of Medicine provides access to datasets from National Library of Medicine resources and research. This service is new but is expected to grow in the future.

Library Search

You can use Library Search to find datasets. Use advanced search and select the resource type datasets.

Research guides

Datasets and data repositories

Finding and using data from ICPSR

attributes.label: Community computer lab
attributes.title: Community computer lab
attributes.description:
The Community Computer Program was established in 2009 under former Dean of Temple Libraries Larry Alford. Participants in the program are non-Temple affiliates, majority of user population consists of Philadelphia residents and others living in the tri-state area. Members of the program include Temple alumni. There are twelve community computers with Microsoft Suite Software, a black and white change operated printer, two scanners, and a charging station for all cellular devices. Community members and alumni are permitted two hours a day on computers, additional time may be given as a courtesy at staff discretion. All on-site computers have access to university licensed academic databases.

Two types of community members: Computer Users & PA Borrowers. Both arrive at our main service point and apply. A current valid state issued ID is necessary and an active email to create their account in our ILS system. Computer Users may only use computers and have access to printers, scanners, and charging stations. PA Borrowers are subject to the same criteria to apply but must have a state issued ID with a current PA address and have the same access as Computer Users but may also check out up to ten library books.

Community members are subject to Temple police approval of applicants and agree to abide by Library Code of Conduct when signing up. Submission and processing time of applicants can take up to two weeks Alumni using the Community Computers must attain an Alumni Card from the Alumni Office in Sullivan Hall. Once this ID is received, they can use all listed resources and check out up to ten books and/or movies.

Student Tech Assistants employed by the library in the Community Computer Lab aid community members and alumni in navigating university resources and providing supplemental technological service. Workshops held in Job Readiness such as resume formatting, cover letter construction, and professional etiquette are open to community members that utilize these skills on the computers. Likewise GED completion programs conducted by PASCEP on campus can be applied to and navigated from the computers.

attributes.label: Borrow books & DVDs
attributes.title: Borrow books & DVDs
attributes.description:
Use your Owlcard to check out books, journals, and DVD/VHS at each of our Temple Libraries locations. Loan periods for items are listed below.

Renew items

Renew your books online through My Library Account or call any of our service desks

Return items

Books and media may be returned at any TU library location. Reserve items must be returned to the library from which they were borrowed and may not be placed in the drop-bins.

Pay late & lost item fees

We charge fees for late, damaged, or lost items. These fees help us provide all of our users with consistent and reliable access to our collections.

Do you have questions about a late fee or lost item charge? We can work with you to resolve most fee issues at any service desk. Acceptable forms of payment include credit/debit cards, Diamond Dollars and personal check.

Reserves & non-circulating items

Some materials can only be used in the library, including reserves, items in our Special Collections Research Center, newspapers, microfilm, and maps.

Books are loaned for use in the library for up to three hours at a time and DVDs are loaned for use in the library for up to four hours.

attributes.label: The Automated Storage and Retrieval System (BookBot)
attributes.title: The Automated Storage and Retrieval System (BookBot)
attributes.description:
The Temple University ASRS, located in the Charles Library, is a state of the art automated storage and retrieval system containing nearly 1.5 million volumes. When a book or bound journal is requested via our online catalog, it relays a message to the ASRS system requesting the desired material. The ASRS then initiates the request and the book is delivered to a processing station to be readied for patron pick up.

Read more information about borrowing books from the BookBot.
